Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: The regular weekly Shabbat service is approaching.
Story: I stare at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the code sample from my mentor half-finished. The logic is tricky, and I know he expects me to have it polished before our next meeting in three days. My phone buzzes with a reminder: Shabbat is coming. As the rabbi, I need to prepare a sermon that will inspire and comfort my congregation. They look to me for guidance, especially this week, after the loss in our community. My mind races between debugging lines of code and searching for the right words for my sermon. I feel the weight of my mentor’s trust—he’s invested so much in my growth, and I don’t want to let him down. At the same time, my congregation expects me to be present, thoughtful, and prepared. The hours slip by, and I feel torn, pulled by two worlds that both matter deeply to me. My heart aches with the pressure, knowing I can’t give less than my best to either.
